content: The federal K-12 education legislation, starting from the Improving America's Schools Act in 1994 to the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001, has focused on granting flexibility to grantees. This flexibility allows for waivers of federal program requirements for state and local recipients meeting certain criteria. The report provides an overview of these authorizations and will be updated as needed to incorporate new developments. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) is not included in this discussion due to its unique requirements and lack of flexibility authorities.
